## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 22, 2023 - November 28, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-11-30T00:07:04Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-11-22T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-11-28T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20231130-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with 5 M-class flares, 1 O-type CME, and 13 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center it was estimated that the combined leading edge of the C-type CMEs first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-11-27T06:48Z, 2023-11-27T20:12Z, and 2023-11-27T23:48Z may impact OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-29T07:17Z, Psyche at 2023-12-01T10:27Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-30T07:48Z, STEREO A at 2023-11-30T06:52Z, and NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-11-30T13:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a roughly estimated maximum Kp range of 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notifications 20231127-AL-001, 20231128-AL-001, and 20231128-AL-004).

The C-type CMEs first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-11-28T20:24Z and 2023-11-28T20:48Z associated with the M3.4 class flare peaking at 2023-11-28T19:32Z and the M9.8 class flare peaking at 2023-11-28T19:50Z from Active Region 13500 (S16W00) were simulated and the combined leading edge of the CMEs may impact OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-30T09:11Z, Psyche at 2023-12-01T15:12Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-30T22:24Z, and STEREO A at 2023-12-01T04:50Z (plus minus 7 hours). Simulations also indicate that the combined leading edge of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-12-01T06:45Z with a roughly estimated maximum Kp range of 5-7 (minor to strong) (see notification 20231129-AL-001).

In addition, the following CMEs were estimated to impact NASA missions near Earth:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impact (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-11-22T21:36Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2023-11-25T17:01Z, Kp index 4-6 (below minor to moderate)
                                       See notifications 20231123-AL-001, 20231124-AL-004
                                       Ensemble results: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-24_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA053/Detailed_results_20231123_014000_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA053.txt
                                       The arrival of this CME may have been detected at L1 around 2023-11-25T07:59Z.
2023-11-23T06:12Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2023-11-26T10:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 2-4 (below minor)
                                       See notification 20231124-AL-003
                                       The arrival of this CME was not detected at L1.
2023-11-24T10:12Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2023-11-27T06:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 2-4 (below minor)
                                       See notification 20231125-AL-001
                                       The arrival of this CME was not detected at L1.

The CMEs listed below were simulated to impact the following locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-11-22T01:48Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-11-24T20:00Z (glancing blow), Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-24T16:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231122-AL-003)
2023-11-22T21:36Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-24T20:30Z, Psyche at 2023-11-26T02:38Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-25T05:38Z, STEREO A at 2023-11-25T16:05Z, and Juno at 2023-12-10T00:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231123-AL-001 and 20231124-AL-004)
2023-11-23T03:12Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-11-23T22:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231123-AL-002)
2023-11-23T06:00Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-11-24T20:11Z (see notification 20231124-AL-003)
2023-11-23T06:12Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-11-24T20:11Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-25T13:00Z (glancing blow), Psyche at 2023-11-27T00:00Z (glancing blow), Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-25T15:00Z (glancing blow), and STEREO A at 2023-11-26T12:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231124-AL-003)
2023-11-24T10:12Z  OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-26T08:47Z, Psyche at 2023-11-27T14:00Z (glancing blow), STEREO A at 2023-11-27T02:00Z (glancing blow), and Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-27T01:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231125-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 6 during the reporting period (see notifications 20231125-AL-005, 20231125-AL-006). The highest value of Kp = 6 occurred during the synoptic period 2023-11-25T18:00Z-21:00Z. This enhanced geomagnetic activity was likely caused by the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream at L1 on 2023-11-24 and the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-11-25T07:59Z which was likely associated with the arrival of the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-11-22T21:36Z (see notification 20231125-AL-003). Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-11-25T09:28Z (see notifications 20231125-AL-002 and 20231125-AL-004). The arrival of this CME may have also been detected by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments around 2023-11-25T04:30Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-11-24T14:15Z (see notifications 20231124-AL-001 and 20231124-AL-002). These elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely caused by the arrival of the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-11-16T03:48Z detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 at 2023-11-20T09:49Z and the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream at L1 on 2021-11-21 observed during the previous reporting period. Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-11-22T05:40Z (see notifications 20231122-AL-001 and 20231122-AL-002) due to the arrival of this coronal hole high speed stream. The elevated > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES returned to background levels on 2023-11-25 and remained at background levels through the remainder of the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-11-29T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-12-05T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at low to moderate levels during the outlook period. Currently, there are numerous numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13500 (currently located at S19W15) produced 2 M-class flares during the reporting period and is likely to produce further flaring activity during the outlook period. Active Region 13499 (currently located at S17W70) produced C-class flares and one M-class flare during the reporting period and may continue to exhibit flaring activity before rotating off of the Earth-facing disk on or around 2023-12-01.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to reach minor or strong levels during the outlook period. A notable increase in geomagnetic activity may be observed around 2023-11-30 and 2023-12-01 due to the anticipated arrivals of the C-type CMEs from 2023-11-27 and 2023-11-28 previously described above. Additionally, a large coronal hole structure currently centered near S10W30 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) could become geoeffective towards the end of the outlook period on or around 2023-12-04.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-11-28T20:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~910 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 13/0 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-11-28T20:24:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-11-28T20:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~768 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 2/-6 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-11-28T20:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may affect OSIRIS-APEX, Psyche, Solar Orbiter, and STEREO A. The combined leading edge of the CMEs will reach OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-30T09:11Z, Psyche at 2023-12-01T15:12Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-30T22:24Z, and STEREO A at 2023-12-01T04:50Z (plus minus 7 hours). 
  
The simulation also indicates that the CMEs may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the combined leading edge of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-12-01T06:45Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 5-7 (minor to strong).

## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2023-11-27T06:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20231127-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 32 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge or flank of the CME will reach:
- STEREO A between about 2023-11-29T08:14Z and 2023-11-30T06:24Z (average arrival 2023-11-29T18:30Z) for 100% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-11-29T10:25Z and 2023-11-30T12:18Z (average arrival 2023-11-29T21:47Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 83% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-27_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054/20231127_100600_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-27_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054/20231127_100600_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-27_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054/20231127_100600_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-27_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054/20231127_100600_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-27_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054/20231127_100600_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
This CME event (2023-11-27T06:48:00-CME-001) is also predicted to have an impact at 
OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-29T07:54Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-30T11:25Z, and Psyche at 2023-11-30T19:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20231127-AL-001).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-27_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054/Detailed_results_20231127_100600_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA054.txt

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2023-11-22T21:36:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20231123-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 32 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2023-11-25T08:47Z and 2023-11-26T03:30Z (average arrival 2023-11-25T17:18Z) for 100% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-11-25T09:28Z and 2023-11-26T04:41Z (average arrival 2023-11-25T18:13Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 71% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-6 range (below minor to moderate).

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2023-11-24T14:15Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely caused by the arrival of the CME with ID 2023-11-16T03:48:00-CME-001 detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 at 2023-11-20T09:49Z and a subsequent arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2023-11-21. Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-11-22T05:40Z (see notifications 20231122-AL-001 and 20231122-AL-002). The maximum sustained solar wind speed at L1 reached approximately 550km/s. The solar wind speed is currently around 350km/s. 

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-11-24T14:15:00-RBE-001.

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2023-11-09T12:23Z would impact NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-11-11T21:05Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 4-6 (below minor to moderate) (see notification 20231109-AL-002). An ensemble simulation was performed for this CME with 32 members which estimated the CME to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-11-11T11:35Z and 2023-11-12T00:18Z (average arrival 2023-11-11T18:24Z) for 100% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicated that there is a 93% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-6 range (below minor to moderate). Full details of the modeled event are available here: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-09_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052/Detailed_results_20231109_122300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052.txt (see notification 20231110-AL-001). The arrival of this CME was likely detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2023-11-12T05:30Z. STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data may have also detected the arrival of this CME around 2023-11-12T03:48Z.

It was also estimated that the following CME would impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-11-09T12:23Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-11T09:36Z, Psyche at 2023-11-11T22:29Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-11T05:44Z, and STEREO A at 2023-11-11T17:55Z (see notification 20231109-AL-002). 

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5.00 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5.00 occurred during the synoptic period 2023-11-13T00:00Z-03:00Z. This minor enhancement of geomagnetic activity was caused by the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-11-12T05:30Z which was likely associated with the arrival of the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2023-11-09T12:23Z. The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A remained near or slightly above background levels throughout the entire reporting period.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-11-10T09:10Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-11-07T15:35Z (see notifications 20231107-AL-001, 20231107-AL-002, and 20231109-AL-001) are caused by the consecutive arrivals of CME with ID 2023-11-02T03:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20231102-AL-002 and 20231103-AL-001) and CME with ID 2023-11-03T05:48:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20231103-AL-002 and 20231104-AL-001) as well as a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived at L1 on 2023-11-06. The arrival of these CMEs were detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-11-05T08:10Z (see notifications 20231105-AL-003 and 20231105-AL-004) and 2023-11-05T11:45Z, respectively. The solar wind speed at L1 reached a maximum of approximately 750 km/s as observed by ACE.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-11-07T15:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 

The CME arrivals are associated with a geomagnetic storm with ID 2023-11-05T09:00:00-GST-001 (see notifications 20231105-AL-002, 20231105-AL-005, 20231105-AL-007, and 20231105-AL-008). Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic period 2023-11-05T15:00Z-T18:00Z. Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-11-05T10:34Z (see notifications 20231105-AL-001 and 20231105-AL-006) after the first detected CME arrival and again at 2023-11-05T14:52Z after the second detected CME arrival.

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-11-09T11:35Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-11-07T15:35Z (see notifications 20231107-AL-001 and 20231107-AL-002) are caused by the combined arrival of CME with ID 2023-11-02T03:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20231102-AL-002 and 20231103-AL-001) and CME with ID 2023-11-03T05:48:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20231103-AL-002 and 20231104-AL-001) as well as a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived at L1 on 2023-11-06. The arrival of these CMEs was detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-11-05T08:10Z (see notifications 20231105-AL-003 and 20231105-AL-004) and 2023-11-05T11:45Z, respectively. The solar wind speed at L1 reached a maximum of approximately 750 km/s as observed by ACE.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-11-07T15:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

The CME arrivals are associated with a geomagnetic storm with ID 2023-11-05T09:00:00-GST-001 (see notifications 20231105-AL-002, 20231105-AL-005, 20231105-AL-007, and 20231105-AL-008). Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic period 2023-11-05T15:00Z-T18:00Z. Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-11-05T10:34Z (see notifications 20231105-AL-001 and 20231105-AL-006) after the first detected CME arrival and again at 2023-11-05T14:52Z after the second detected CME arrival.

2023-11-05T16:53Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2023-11-07T22:00Z (see notification 20231106-AL-001).


Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=7 for the reporting period (see notifications 20231105-AL-002, 20231105-AL-005, 20231105-AL-007, and 20231105-AL-008). The highest value of Kp = 7 occurred during the synoptic period of 2023-11-05T15:00Z-18:00Z. This enhanced geomagnetic activity was associated with the back-to-back interplanetary shocks detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-11-05T08:10Z (see notifications 20231105-AL-003 and 20231105-AL-004) and at 2023-11-05T11:45Z, which were associated with the arrivals of the C-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2023-11-02T03:36Z (see notifications 20231102-AL-002 and 20231103-AL-001) and at 2023-11-03T05:48Z (see notifications 20231103-AL-002 and 20231104-AL-001), respectively. Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-11-05T10:34Z (see notifications 20231105-AL-001 and 20231105-AL-006) after the first detected CME arrival and again at 2023-11-05T14:52Z after the second detected CME arrival. The arrival of these C-type CMEs initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-11-02T03:36Z and 2023-11-03T05:48Z were also detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data around 2023-11-05T03:38Z and 2023-11-05T12:35Z, respectively.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt remained elevated above the threshold of 1000 pfu throughout the first part of the reporting period following a threshold crossing observed during the previous reporting period at 2023-10-29T15:20Z (see notifications 20231029-AL-001, 20231029-AL-002, 20231031-AL-001, 20231102-AL-003, and 20231104-AL-002). These elevated electron fluxes returned to background levels on 2023-11-04. Towards the end of the reporting period, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux crossed the 1000 pfu threshold at 2023-11-07T15:35Z (see notifications 20231107-AL-001 and 20231107-AL-002) due to the back-to-back arrivals of the C-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2023-11-02T03:36Z and 2023-11-03T05:48Z (previously described above) and a subsequent coronal hole high speed stream arrival detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE on 2023-11-06.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-11-08T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-11-14T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently six numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing solar disk. Active Region 13480 (S08E02) produced three of the 6 M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to show similar level flaring activity during the outlook period. Active Region 13483 (N10W09) and Active Region 13477 (S15W22) may also exhibit C-level and possible M-class flaring activity during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. The large coronal hole structure that crossed the Earth-facing central meridian on 2023-11-04 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) reached geoeffective longitudes towards the end of the reporting period and is associated with a coronal hole high speed stream arrival detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE on 2023-11-06. Continued influences from this associated coronal hole high speed stream may be observed during the beginning of the outlook period. A smaller coronal hole centered near S30E20 is anticipated to cross the central meridian on or around 2023-11-10 and may become geoeffective towards the end of the outlook period on or around 2023-11-14. Additionally, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt currently remains enhanced (see notifications 20231107-AL-001 and 20231107-AL-002) and this elevated electron flux may persist into the beginning of the outlook period.

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare, 1 O-type CME, and 6 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs would impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-10-25T13:37Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-27T22:02Z (see notification 20231025-AL-003)
2023-10-26T23:14Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-28T09:58Z and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-28T10:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231027-AL-001)
2023-10-31T21:12Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-11-02T15:48Z and Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-02T20:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231101-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4.67 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4.67 occurred during four synoptic periods. The value of Kp=4.67 occurring during the synoptic periods ending on 2023-10-26T12:00Z and 2023-10-27T00:00Z was likely caused by the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-10-26T03:43Z, which was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE on 2023-10-26. This interplanetary shock arrival may have also been detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data around 2023-10-26T11:10Z. Further enhancements in geomagnetic activity to Kp=4.67 occurred during the synoptic periods ending on 2023-10-29T03:00Z and 2023-10-29T09:00Z and was likely associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE on 2023-10-28. This coronal hole high speed stream arrival may have also been detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data on 2023-10-28. The solar wind speed reached values of around 550 km/s and 570 km/s, respectively. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-10-29T15:20Z (see notifications 20231029-AL-001 and 20231029-AL-002). Subsequently, towards the end of the reporting period, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux crossed the 1000 pfu threshold at 2023-10-31T12:50Z (see notification 20231031-AL-001). These elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely associated with the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream at L1 on 2023-10-28 described above. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-11-01T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-11-07T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor to moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently six numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing solar disk. The recent M-class flaring in the southeast may be attributable to Active Region 13477 (S15E80) and possibly an additional unnumbered region visible in SDO imagery near the eastern limb around latitude S10 and may continue throughout the outlook period. Additional minor flaring activity may occur throughout the outlook period from recently numbered Active Region 13478 (N12E70).

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A prominent coronal hole structure centered around S20E40 but with a portion extending meridionally through the equator to about N20 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective starting on or around 2023-11-07. Additional enhancements in geomagnetic activity may be observed during the outlook period in association with the potential arrival of a C-type CME first observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-10-31T22:12Z. Additionally, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt remains enhanced at the start of the outlook period (see notifications 20231029-AL-001, 20231029-AL-002, and 20231031-AL-001) and this elevation is likely to persist into the outlook period.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-10-31T12:50Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-10-29T15:20Z are caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived at L1 on 2023-10-28, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 625 km/s at DSCOVR (see notifications 20231029-AL-001 and 20231029-AL-002). The solar wind speed at L1 is currently around 490 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-10-29T15:20:00-RBE-001.
